title: 115_s1072
content:
The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans and establishes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness. The Secretary will enter into partnerships to fund general legal services for homeless veterans, ensuring equitable distribution across the United States, including rural communities and tribal lands. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness. Legal services include housing-related assistance, family law support, income support, and criminal defense to reduce recidivism and help with reentry obstacles. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships for legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, including defense for issues like outstanding warrants and driver's license revocation. The Secretary may require periodic reports on services provided. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. The subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include eligibility criteria for veterans receiving assistance or care in specific settings. Eligible veterans must be enrolled for care and receiving assistance for 60 consecutive days. The subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include eligibility criteria for veterans receiving assistance or care in specific settings. The Secretary may disregard breaks in the continuity of assistance or care for which the veteran is not responsible. SEC. 5. Repeal of sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness transitioning from certain institutions. Amends Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d).

SEC. 6. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. Amends section 2044(e) of title 38, United States Code by adjusting funding for fiscal year 2017 to $500,000,000 and extending training entities for provision of supportive services through 2017.

SEC. 7. Requirement for Comptroller General to study Department of Veterans Affairs homeless veterans programs. SEC. 7. The Comptroller General of the United States will study Department of Veterans Affairs programs assisting homeless veterans within 270 days of this Act. The study will assess program effectiveness for eligible veterans and review efforts to enhance privacy, safety, and security for female veterans.
